message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). 5-alpha reductase inhibitors are used to treat BPH by reducing the size of the prostate. Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists can also alleviate symptoms by relaxing smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, but they do not reduce the size of the prostate. Anticholinergics and phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors are not used to treat BPH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms indicate benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and the smooth, severely enlarged prostate without nodules suggests BPH-related bladder outlet obstruction. 5-alpha reductase inhibitors, such as finasteride and dutasteride, reduce the size of the prostate by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, which plays a major role in the development and progression of BPH. Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists, such as terazosin and tamsulosin, relax the smooth muscle in the prostate and improve urine flow, but do not reduce the size of the prostate. Anticholinergics, such as oxybutynin and solifenacin, are used to treat overactive bladder symptoms but are not effective for BPH-related urinary symptoms. Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors, such as sildenafil and tadalafil, are used to treat erectile dysfunction and pulmonary hypertension, but are not effective for BPH-related urinary symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). 5-alpha reductase inhibitors are used to treat BPH by reducing the size of the prostate. Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists are also used to treat BPH but they work by relaxing smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, improving urine flow. Anticholinergics are used to treat overactive bladder, which is not the main problem in this patient. Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors are used to treat erectile dysfunction, which is not relevant to this patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and enlarged prostate without nodules suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which can be treated with 5-alpha reductase inhibitors such as finasteride or dutasteride. These drugs reduce the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, which can help reduce the size of the prostate and alleviate symptoms. Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists are also used to treat BPH, but they work by relaxing the smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, rather than reducing the size of the prostate. Anticholinergics and phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors are not used to treat BPH.

The symptoms and physical examination suggest the patient has benign prostatic hyperplasia, and among the options, only 5-alpha reductase inhibitors can reduce the size of the prostate by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists can improve urine flow by relaxing smooth muscle but do not reduce prostate size. Anticholinergics and phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors are not used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The enlarged prostate causing urinary symptoms suggests benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). 5-alpha reductase inhibitors reduce prostate size by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, which stimulates prostate growth. Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists also relax the prostate and bladder to relieve symptoms but do not reduce the size of the prostate. Anticholinergics are used for overactive bladder and urinary incontinence, and phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors are used for erectile dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and the drug prescribed to reduce the size of the prostate is most likely a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor, which inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, thus reducing the size of the prostate. Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists can also be used for BPH to relax smooth muscles in the bladder and prostate. Anticholinergic and phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors are not typically used for BPH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is caused by the overgrowth of prostate tissue due to the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). 5-alpha reductase inhibitors can inhibit this conversion, reducing the size of the prostate and relieving the symptoms. Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists can also alleviate BPH symptoms by relaxing the smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, but do not affect the size of the prostate. Anticholinergics are used for overactive bladder symptoms and have no effect on BPH. Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors are used for erectile dysfunction and have no effect on BPH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and an enlarged prostate. A 5-alpha reductase inhibitor like finasteride or dutasteride can reduce the size of the prostate and improve urinary symptoms. Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists relax smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck and are also commonly used to treat BPH, but they do not directly reduce prostate size. Anticholinergic medications are not used to treat BPH. Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors like sildenafil are used to treat erectile dysfunction, not BPH.

Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists are also used to treat BPH but they do not reduce the size of the prostate. Anticholinergics and phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors are not used to treat BPH.
